Table 1 ΔG (kcal/mol) 2H2O 10.8 4H2O 8.0 6H2O 6.6 8H2O 11.2 Old dog, new tricks: DFT insights into the hydrolysis of NH3BH3 by Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts Kehan Qian Writing – original draft Yong Wang Supervision ⁎ College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Soochow University Suzhou 215123 China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The Grubbs catalyst, a classic catalyst used for the metathesis of alkenes, was first used for the hydrolysis of ammonia borane. A density functional theory study was carried out to explore the mechanism by which the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst facilitates the hydrolysis of ammonia borane, producing three equivalents of H2 through detailed mechanistic pathways. Whether the dissociation of chloride anions occurs or not has a crucial influence on the reaction mechanism. The computational results indicate that upon the dissociation of chloride anions, the coordination of ammonia borane with the catalyst is capable of forming a stable intermediate. Subsequently, this intermediate undergoes the nucleophilic attack of H2O and the activation process of the O–H bond, eventually generating H2. All three hydrogen generation cycles exhibit a similar catalytic mechanism. Through energy decomposition analysis (EDA), an independent gradient model based on the Hirshfeld partition method (IGMH), and Fukui functions, the energy sources of competing transition states, reaction sites, and intermolecular interaction forces are investigated. Graphical abstract Mechanistic insights into the Ru-catalyzed AB hydrolysis dehydrogenation are carefully investigated by DFT theory. The dissociation of chloride anions is conducive to the progress with a lower energy barrier. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia borane Hydrolysis mechanism Energy decomposition analysis Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst Density function theory Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction As traditional fossils are being depleted, it is increasingly clear that new, clean energy sources must replace traditional energy. Among the options for sustainable energy, hydrogen (H2) stands out for its cleanliness and high abundance [1–3]. Consequently, devising efficient methods for hydrogen production and storage has emerged as a key area of research. Owing to its extremely high hydrogen capacity (19.6 wt % hydrogen in AB), Ammonia borane (NH3BH3, AB) is a leading component for practical use as a chemical hydrogen storage material [4–6]. Theoretically, one molecule of AB can release three molecules of H2. Over the past few decades, researchers have extensively studied the use of metal catalysts, both homogeneous and heterogeneous, to understand the extent and rate of hydrogen release from ammonia borane. Two primary pathways for the dehydrogenation of AB have been distinguished: pyrolysis and hydrolysis. With respect to thermal dehydrogenation, researchers have carried out experiments to evaluate the catalytic activity of transition metal catalysts. Numerous transition metal catalysts have shown outstanding performance, including costly metals such as Ru [7], Pd [8], Rh [9], and less expensive metals such as Fe [10], Co [11], and Mo [12]. Based on these experiments, researchers have engaged in thorough discussions of the thermal dehydrogenation mechanism of AB. Paul and Musgrave reported that the dehydrogenation of AB was catalyzed by the Ir-pincer complex [POCOPtBuIr(H)2] through a concerted elimination process involving B–H and N–H bonds [13]. Weller reported that under the catalysis of Rh(I) complexes, ammonia borane is dehydrogenated stepwise with the activation of B–H/N–H bonds [14]. Yang and Hall found that the dehydrogenation of AB via Ni(NHC)2 involves a proton transfer process [15]. However, the thermal dehydrogenation of AB typically fails to release three equivalents of H2 completely, limiting its full potential. Unlike thermal dehydrogenation, during the hydrolysis of ammonia borane, the H atoms in the borane moiety engage in a cooperative interaction with water molecules, leading to the liberation of three equivalents of H₂. Historically, the hydrolysis of ammonia borane has been carried out primarily via heterogeneous catalysts, such as Pd [16], Pt [17], and Co [18]. However, the use of homogeneous metal-based catalysts for the hydrolysis dehydrogenation of AB based on Ir(III) complexes was first reported in 2010 (Scheme 1 ). Amoroso et al. utilized Ir complexes with PNP ligands to catalyze the hydrolysis of ammonia borane at 40 °C in an iPrOH/H2O (1:1) solvent [19]. In 2011, Nolan reported the hydrolysis of AB catalyzed by Ir-NHC complexes [20]. They hypothesized that the reaction occurred through B–N bond dissociation; however, a recent study demonstrated this pathway is unfavorable [21]. Instead, the carbene-assisted proton transfer mechanism is more favorable. Additionally, [Ru(p-cymene)(bpy)Cl]Cl was found to be effective in promoting AB hydrolysis by Freixa et al. in 2017 [22]. Based on experimental observations, the authors proposed a stepwise mechanism. Initially, the nucleophilic attack by a H2O molecule, followed by the O–H bond activation, resulting in H2 generation. Despite the well-established mechanistic explanations for the thermal dehydrogenation of ammonia borane, the theoretical development of the homogeneous hydrolysis process has been significantly slower. In 2017, Li et al. reported a proton transfer mechanism assisted by oxygen negative ions, which also involved an oxidation–reduction reaction [23]. In 2019, they further reported a mechanism in which two hydrogen atoms were successively transferred to the metal center before the formation of H2 [24]. In 2021, Hu reported that CAAC iridium complexes could catalyze the hydrolysis of AB without direct coordination with ammonia borane [25]. Notably, their work uniformly supports the experimental observations that half of the three equivalents of H2 are derived from BH3, and the other half from H2O. This provides robust theoretical support for the experimental findings. Interestingly, in 2020, Tuba and colleagues reported the use of Hoveyda−Grubbs-like catalysts to catalyze the hydrolysis of ammonia borane in water, thereby releasing hydrogen gas, as depicted in Scheme 2 [26]. These catalysts exhibit remarkably high turnover frequencies (TOF) and turnover numbers (TON), demonstrating outstanding catalytic performance. At 10 ppm loading, the TON and TOF can reach 56,000 [mol H2 molcat −1] and 8190 [molH2 molcat −1 h−1], respectively. To the best of our knowledge, Grubbs catalysts were originally designed to catalyze the metathesis of alkenes [27,28]. This is the first time that Grubbs series of catalysts have been used to catalyze the hydrolysis of AB. In addition to the production of nearly three equivalents of H2, 11B NMR analysis of the reaction mixture revealed that the borates were the primary products. The possibility of a catalytic reaction by ruthenium nanoparticles was ruled out by the addition of mercury to eliminate the ruthenium nanoparticles. Unfortunately, owing to the use of water as the solvent, the formation of the proposed CAAC-Ru-H species could not be detected, leaving the reaction mechanism mysterious. Why can the Grubbs catalyst catalyze the hydrolysis of ammonia borane? Given the limited applicability of Grubbs catalysts in aqueous systems [29,30], chloride anion dissociation has emerged as a critical issue requiring further investigation. To gain a better understanding of the mechanism by which Grubbs catalysts operate in the catalytic hydrolysis of AB and to contribute to the development of hydrogen energy applications, density functional theory (DFT) computations were utilized herein. 2 Computational details By employing the practical density functional theory approach, all the structures of the intermediates and transition states were optimized using the Gaussian 16 program [31]. For geometry optimization, the PBE0 functional [32,33] with D3-BJ dispersion correction [34] was employed to reveal the reaction details. The LANL2TZ [35,36] basis set was used to describe the Ru atom, whereas the 6–31G(d,p) [37,38] basis set was used for all other atoms, such as C, H, B, N and Cl. Vibrational calculations were performed at the same level of theory and the stationary points were verified as minima (no imaginary frequencies) and transition state (TS) (only one imaginary frequency) to obtain the thermal energy corrections at 298.15 K. Solvation by water was considered using the integral equation formalism polarizable continuum model (IEFPCM) [39] for optimizations and frequencies. To further validate the accuracy of the transition state, intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) [40,41] calculations were conducted to ensure that all transition states were indeed connected to the corresponding intermediates and products. Subsequently, using the PBE0-D3BJ functional, the triple-ζ def2-TZVPP [42] basis set, with solvation effects of water accounted for by the SMD (solvation model density) solvent model [43], which is expected to provide an accurate energy level, single-point calculations were performed to obtain the electronic energy. All 3D structures were depicted using CYLview software [44]. Additionally, to investigate the weak interactions of important transition states, the independent gradient model based on the Hirshfeld partition method (IGMH) [45] was employed. Mayer bond [46] was used for the analysis of the bond order of chemical bonds, and the Fukui function [47,48] was utilized to analyze the reaction sites. The 3D renderings of surfaces were generated through the Multiwfn program [49,50], and visualized by the VMD program [51]. 3 Results and discussion In the absence of a catalyst, the calculated energy barrier for the hydrolysis of ammonia borane is 46.5 kcal/mol (Fig. S1), rendering an effective reaction at 25 °C highly improbable. Therefore, future studies will focus on elucidating the hydrolysis mechanism under catalytic conditions. Considering that the efficacies of catalysts 1 and 2 (Scheme 2) reported by Tuba et al. are similar, catalyst 1 was selected to simplify the calculations. As depicted in Fig. 1 , although many studies [52,53] have confirmed that chloride anions (Cl–) do not undergo dissociation during catalysis by Grubbs catalysts, the energy variation with the potential dissociation of Cl– was carefully investigated, considering the differences in solvents. Considering the ion exchange between H2O and chloride anions in solution, as well as the formation of weak hydrogen bonds between chloride anions and H2O, this study takes into account varying numbers of H2O in the hydration shell surrounding the chloride anions, as shown in Table 1 . The H2O molecules are evenly distributed around two chloride anions. The computational results demonstrate that when the number of H2O reaches six, the energy required for ion exchange is minimized to 6.6 kcal/mol. This indicates that under these conditions, the undissociated state of chloride anions exhibits greater stability relative to the catalyst. Therefore, in the context of the subsequent catalytic hydrolysis process, the scenarios of undissociated and dissociated chloride anions would be examined in detail in Sections 3.1 and 3.2, respectively. 3.1 Chloride anions do not dissociate The coordination mode between ammonia borane and the catalyst was subsequently investigated, as shown in Fig. 2 . Catalyst 1 can directly coordinate with AB in the form of a five-coordinate complex (1-a) with an endothermic energy of 14.2 kcal/mol. The angle C1–Ru–O in 1 is 178.0°, whereas that in 1-a is 160.1° Moreover, AB could coordinate with the Ru metal center through a 3-center, 2-electron B–H–Ru single bond in η2 binding mode to form an intermediate (INT1). In this case, the coordination bond between O and Ru is cleaved. The moiety beneath Ru undergoes a significant inversion, with the dihedral angle N–C1–Ru–O changing from –95.6° in 1 to 31.2° in INT1. This coordination complex experiences an energy increase of 7.8 kcal/mol compared with that of the original catalyst 1, which is lower than that of 1-a. Therefore, INT1, as the active intermediate, is considered and proceeds with the catalytic cycle from this point, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . Apart from TS1–2, starting from INT1, the excitation of H1 on the other side to the carbine C1 above transition state TS1–2′ is also taken into account and presented in Fig. S2. Nevertheless, in contrast to TS1–2, TS1–2′ possesses a higher energy barrier and therefore is not a favorable reaction path. B–H Activation. In INT1, the B–H1, B–H2, Ru–H1, Ru–H2, and B–Ru bond distances are 1.23 Å, 1.26 Å, 2.12 Å, 1.90 Å, and 2.40 Å (Fig. 4 ), respectively. Starting from INT1, H2 is activated and added to carbene C2. Consequently, the B…Ru distance is shortened from 2.40 Å to 2.17 Å, and the B–H1 bond distance is lengthened to 1.76 Å. The optimized transition state (TS), denoted as TS1–2, clearly illustrates the process of B–H bond cleavage and the gradual formation of the B–Ru bond, which is analogous to hydroboration. Consequently, intermediate INT2 is formed by the creation of a new saturated carbon atom and the B–Ru bond. The predicted Gibbs energy barrier of this step is 16.3 kcal/mol, and the formed INT2 is thermodynamically unstable by 5.2 kcal/mol relative to INT1. In INT2, the B–Ru distance is shortened to 2.09 Å. In the reaction of alkene metathesis catalyzed by the Grubbs catalyst, the alkene will undergo a transition state with Ru=C, which resembles a [2 + 2] cycloaddition step [52]. However, a similar reaction occurs in ammonia borane, despite the absence of the double bond, which piques our interest. To provide a more comprehensive understanding of the reaction process, we conducted Millikan charge and ADCH [54] charge analyses for INT1, TS1–2, and INT2, as depicted in Fig. 4. The green color represents the Millikan charge, while the purple color signifies the ADCH charge. Throughout this reaction process, the Ru metal center serves as the charge carrier. Initially, the proton H2 transfers some of its charge to Ru, and B donates a portion of its electrons to the metal center. Subsequently, both Ru and the proton H2 transfer some of their charges to C2, thus completing the reaction. Moreover, we performed IGMH analysis to examine the forces acting on the proton during the transfer process, as shown in Fig. 5 . IGMH analyses leverage integrated electron densities to quantify the strengths of chemical bonds. The interaction between specific regions is visualized using the reduced density gradient (RDG) method. In RDG diagrams, green regions represent van der Waals interactions, and blue regions indicate strong attractive interactions (such as hydrogen bonds and halogen bonds). The intensity of the color correlates with the strength of the force. During transfer, NH3BH3 is influenced primarily by the forces exerted by Ru and the carbene. The Ru center not only facilitates proton transfer but also stabilizes the electron-deficient borenium cation. Mayer bond analysis results indicate that the bond order of the B–Ru bond in INT2 is 0.95, confirming the formation of a chemical bond between B and Ru. Sequential H2O Nucleophilic Attack/O–H Activation Pathway or NH Activation Pathway. After INT2, H2O as a nucleophilic reagent attacks the boron center through transition state TS2–3, in which the B…Ru distance is lengthened to 2.14 Å. Consequently, a water-stabilized borenium [NH3BH2(H2O)]+cation in a free state within the complex intermediate INT3 is formed. The predicted Gibbs energy barrier of this step is 15.8 kcal/mol. In contrast, intermediate INT3′ obtained by re-coordinating O with Ru has an energy that is 4.5 kcal/mol higher than that of INT3 (as depicted in Fig. 3), indicating that INT3′ is not the most stable intermediate. Starting from INT3, the O–H bond is activated, and the proton from H2O is transferred to the Ru center through transition state TS3–4, overcoming a relatively low energy barrier of 4.9 kcal/mol. In TS3–4, the O–H bond length is elongated to 1.54 Å. Notably, unlike in TS3–4, INT3 could also lead to the transition state TS3–8, where the proton from NH3 is transferred to carbene C2, resulting in the formation of H2. However, TS3–8 requires an extremely high energy barrier of up to 45.0 kcal/mol, which is kinetically unfavorable and unlikely to occur at room temperature. Alternatively, for TS3–4, TS3–8, and INT3, the distortion/interaction analysis [55] and orbital-weighted Fukui function were performed, as presented in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7 , respectively. As depicted in Fig. 6, the energy differences between the distorted structures and their corresponding optimized ground-state configurations are defined as the distortion energies of the Ru catalyst (ΔEdist-1) and [NH3BH2(H2O)]+ (ΔEdist-2). The interaction energy (ΔEint) represents the energy difference between the total energy of the catalyst plus the substrate and the transition state. The activation energy (ΔE) is the sum of ΔEdist-1, ΔEdist-2 and ΔEint. Clearly, the significant energy separation between TS3–4 and TS3–8 primarily stems from the differences in interaction energy (ΔΔEint = 11.0 kcal/mol) and the distortion energy (ΔΔEdist = 22.1 kcal/mol, ΔΔEdist = ΔΔEdist-1+ ΔΔEdist-2). The distortion energy of the catalyst (ΔΔEdist-1) plays the most significant role in the energy difference between TS3–4 and TS3–8. Both ΔΔEint and ΔΔEdist are positive, suggesting that these two components act synergistically to contribute to the overall energy difference. Fig. 7 illustrates the use of the Fukui function to analyze the reaction sites. The result indicates that the Ru center is an electron-rich region, making the proton of H2O more likely to transfer to Ru instead of directly bonding with the previous proton to form H2. After transition state TS3–4, INT4 can be formed, with a Ru–H distance of 1.55 Å. At this point, NH3BH2(OH) leaves in a free state from INT4. Similar to the attempt to obtain INT3′ by re-coordinating oxygen (O) with Ru, we also tried to re-coordinate O with Ru to obtain INT4′; however, INT4′ had a higher energy than INT4. Subsequently, the protons that were successively transferred to the carbene and Ru approach via the process TS4–5, which has a total energy barrier of 30.2 kcal/mol and is the rate-determining step. After TS4–5, H2 is generated in INT5. Finally, H2 is released from the coordination state, and the previous NH3BH2(OH) re-coordinates with the catalyst via a 3-center, 2-electron B–H–Ru single bond in η2 binding mode in INT6. In INT6, the distances of B–H1 and B–H2 are 1.28 Å and 1.32 Å, respectively, larger than those in INT1. Sequential H2O Nucleophilic Attack/B–H Activation Pathway. Additionally, Tuba and colleagues proposed that the reaction might proceed through a CAAC-Ru-H intermediate. However, since their reactions were conducted in pure water, they encountered difficulties in detecting potential intermediates. Starting from INT1, H2O can directly launch a nucleophilic attack on the B center via transition state TS1–7, overcoming a Gibbs energy barrier of 39.3 kcal/mol. Compared with TS1–2, TS1–7 is 23.0 kcal/mol more energetically unfavorable, indicating a kinetic disadvantage. Following this, the CAAC-Ru-H intermediate INT7 is formed. Subsequently, proton transfer occurs from Ru to carbene C2 through TS7–3, with an energy barrier of 4.4 kcal/mol, leading to the formation of INT3. The Second and Third Equivalents of H2 Release. In the second and third cycles, the process follows a pattern similar to that of the first, as depicted in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9 . Starting from INT6, a proton is activated and transferred to carbene C2 through transition state TS6–9, which requires overcoming an energy barrier of 17.1 kcal/mol, resulting in the formation of INT9. In the presence of external H2O, water molecule acts as a nucleophile and attacks the boron center through transition state TS9–10, forming INT10. This step involves crossing an energy barrier of 13.6 kcal/mol. Subsequently, the proton from H2O dissociates, simultaneously forming a Ru–H bond, via transition state TS10–11, which has an energy barrier of 5.3 kcal/mol. Upon the removal of NH3BH(OH)2 from the catalyst, INT11 is produced. From INT11, the formation of H2 and its release continue. The process from TS11–12 to INT12, which involves the creation of H2, has an energy barrier of 18.8 kcal/mol, resembling those of TS4–5 and INT5 from the initial cycle. After TS11–12 and INT12, H2 is discharged from the Ru center, allowing NH3BH(OH)2 to reattach to Ru by means of both a B–H…Ir single bond and a B–OH…Ir single bond, thereby generating INT13. This consecutive sequence provides an efficient strategy for the synthesis of multiple H2 equivalents via catalytic means. Finally, with the addition of H2O, Fig. 9 reveals the comprehensive mechanism for the release of the third H2 molecule. From INT13, the B–H bond is activated, and the proton is transferred to the carbene via TS13–14, resulting in an energy barrier of 13.5 kcal/mol. In contrast to INT2 and INT9, intermediate INT14 formed at this stage features a far B…Ru distance of 2.90 Å, indicating that no bond is formed between the B atom and the Ru center. However, H2O continues to participate in a nucleophilic reaction with the boron center, leading to the formation of INT15, and the absorption of 6.3 kcal/mol of energy. This process, denoted as TS14–15, might be attributed to the pronounced electron deficiency on boron. Subsequently, the proton of H2O is activated and transferred to Ru through TS15–16, which presents an energy barrier of 6.0 kcal/mol. With the departure of NH3B(OH)3 from the catalyst, INT16 is generated, allowing the continuation of TS16–17 and the formation of intermediate INT17, similar to TS4–5 and INT5 in the first cycle, overcoming an energy barrier of 20.5 kcal/mol. Finally, H2 is released, and the catalyst 1 is restored. It is noteworthy that the energy barrier from 1 to TS4–5 in Fig. 3 is the total energy barrier for the whole reaction, which is 30.2 kcal/mol. 3.2 Chloride anions dissociate As previously discussed, the minimum energy required for ion exchange is 6.6 kcal/mol. During the coordination process of ammonia borane, as shown in Fig. 10 , the original coordination bond between O and Ru undergoes dissociation. Subsequently, ammonia borane coordinates to Ru in a bidentate fashion via its two B–H bonds, forming a cyclic σ-complex, thereby resulting in a reduction of 3.9 kcal/mol in the energy of the system (INT18). It is noteworthy that INT18 is not the most thermodynamically stable intermediate. Upon dissociation of the H2O coordination bond, the five-membered ring below Ru undergoes a folding process, reorienting its plane outward. Concurrently, AB once again coordinates to Ru via two B–H bonds, resulting in the formation of INT19. This intermediate exhibits an energy reduction of 2.7 kcal/mol compared to 1 and is more stable than the previously mentioned INT1, as shown in Fig. 10. In INT19, the bond angle of C1−Ru−O is 98.1°, presenting a stark contrast to the 178.0° in 1. Sequential H2O Nucleophilic Attack/O–H Activation Pathway. Fig. 10 presents the reaction mechanism for the formation of the first equivalent of H2 under the prevailing conditions. During the coordination process, the σ orbital of the B − H bond serves as an electron donor and interacts with the empty d-orbital of the metal, which may be accompanied by the formation of a feedback π-bond, thus resulting in the activation of the B − H bond. In INT19, the B − H3, B − H4 bond distances are 1.37 Å and 1.26 Å, respectively, which demonstrates that the coordination leads to a remarkable elongation of the B − H3 bond, thereby facilitating the subsequent cleavage reaction. Furthermore, the results of the Mayer bond order analysis reveal that the bond orders of the B − H3 and B–H4 are 0.46 and 0.75 respectively, suggesting that the B − H3 bond with the lower bond order is more susceptible to cleavage. Subsequently, H2O initiates a nucleophilic assault on the B center, resulting in the formation of the transition state TS19–20 with the cleavage of the B–H3 bond. This process is accompanied by an energy elevation of 18.7 kcal/mol. Thereafter, the intermediate INT20 is formed, where the B-H bond remains in a coordination state and the NH3 moiety approaches the detached H anion. Nevertheless, this is not the most stable intermediate. Through torsion, while maintaining the coordination of the B − H bond, bringing the H2O moiety close to the detached H leads to an energy reduction of 3.6 kcal/mol, thereby resulting in the formation of a more stable intermediate INT21. From INT21, the proton of H2O undergoes cleavage, and then combines with the previously detached H anion. This process is named as the TS21–22, overcoming an energy barrier of 4.7 kcal/mol. Finally, H2 is produced within the intermediate INT22. As H2 is released and NH3BH2(OH) re-coordinates with the catalyst (INT23), the overall energy of the system becomes more stable, facilitating the generation and release of the second H2 in the subsequent steps. Fig. 11 Apart from the aforementioned content, the reaction mechanism analogous to those referred to in Section 3.1 is also investigated in this part. From INT19, the B–H bond undergoes an addition reaction with Ru=C, leading to the cleavage of the original B–H bond and the formation of a novel B−Ru bond. This transition state (TS19–24) needs to overcome an energy barrier of 44.7 kcal/mol, which is higher than that of TS19–20. Therefore, it is at a disadvantage in terms of kinetics, which is contrary to the situation described earlier (TS1–2 and TS1–7). The comparison of the stability of INT20 and INT21 is of vital importance for determining whether the proton in the formation of H2 primarily originates from H2O or NH3. Hence, the IGMH analysis was conducted using the Multiwfn program. As depicted in Fig. 12 , the higher electron density of the N − H…H interaction in INT20 and the O − H…H interaction in INT21 is manifested. Nevertheless, as the blue region in INT21 is deeper than that in INT20, it suggests that the O − H…H interaction is stronger than the N − H…H interaction, exerting a decisive effect on the stability of INT20 and INT21. To further clarify the source of the proton, the energy barriers of NH bond activation and OH bond activation were compared. Commencing from INT20, the N − H bond is activated, and then the proton is transferred and combined with the previously formed H anion, eventually generating H2, with the energy barrier of 26.9 kcal/mol. Synthesizing the abovementioned conclusions, in contrast to TS21–22 and INT21, the process of NH activation is disadvantageous both thermodynamically and kinetically. This outcome is in accordance with the conclusion derived from experiments. The Second and Third Equivalents of H2 Release. The generation mechanism of the subsequent two equivalents of H2 proceeds along a path similar to that of the aforementioned mechanism, as shown in Fig. 13 and Fig. 14 . Starting from INT23, this reaction process sequentially undergoes nucleophilic attack of H2O (TS23–26), rotation of the bond, and activation of the O–H bond (TS27–28), eventually resulting in the formation of the second equivalent of H2 and NH3BH(OH)2. Finally, H2 is produced and released from the Ru center, allowing NH3BH(OH)2 to bind to Ru via both a B − H…Ru single bond and a B−OH…Ru single bond, thus forming INT29. Subsequently, the third molecule of H2O conducts a nucleophilic assault on the boron center through transition state TS29–30, resulting in the formation of intermediate INT30. After the bond rotation and the activation of the O–H bond, H2 and product NH3B(OH)3 are generated. In contrast to the first cycle, the energy barriers of the following two cycles are lower. Hence, the rate-determining step is from the intermediate INT19 to the transition state TS19–20, with an energy barrier of 18.7 kcal/mol. By integrating the mechanism discussions in Sections 3.1 and 3.2, the catalyst is more stable when the chloride anions remain undissociated. However, when the chloride anions dissociate and the catalyst coordinates with ammonia borane, a more stable active species (INT19) can be generated, and the energy barrier for the subsequent reactions is significantly lowered. Consequently, on the whole, the reaction route after the dissociation of the chloride anions is more advantageous. 4 Conclusions In summary, DFT calculations were carried out to understand the hydrolysis mechanism of Hoveyda−Grubbs catalyzed ammonia borane. The dissociation of chloride anions in the catalyst holds a pivotal influence on the subsequent reaction mechanism. Comparative computational analysis reveals that upon dissociation of chloride anions from the catalyst, the resulting species coordinates with ammonia borane to form a more stable intermediate. This stabilization reduces the energy barrier of the subsequent catalytic cycle, thereby making the overall reaction pathway thermodynamically favorable. After the dissociation of chloride anions, the process proceeds through nucleophilic attack by H2O and activation of the O − H bond, finally leading to H2 generation and release. While such simulation-derived intermediates resist experimental detection, this work offers predictive insights and theoretical foundations to advance catalyst development and reaction mechanism studies. We hope that this study provides novel insight into the mechanistic insights into the hydrolysis of ammonia borane. CRediT authorship contribution statement Kehan Qian: Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: The Grubbs catalyst, a classic catalyst used for the metathesis of alkenes, was first used for the hydrolysis of ammonia borane. A density functional theory study was carried out to explore the mechanism by which the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst facilitates the hydrolysis of ammonia borane, producing three equivalents of H2 through detailed mechanistic pathways. Whether the dissociation of chloride anions occurs or not has a crucial influence on the reaction mechanism. The computational results indicate that upon the dissociation of chloride anions, the coordination of ammonia borane with the catalyst is capable of forming a stable intermediate. Subsequently, this intermediate undergoes the nucleophilic attack of H2O and the activation process of the O–H bond, eventually generating H2. All three hydrogen generation cycles exhibit a similar catalytic mechanism. Through energy decomposition analysis (EDA), an independent gradient model based on the Hirshfeld partition method (IGMH), and Fukui functions, the energy sources of competing transition states, reaction sites, and intermolecular interaction forces are investigated.
